article.title: Quantifying Facial Age by Posterior of Age Comparisons

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of annotation does this figure contrast with existing schemes?
choices: Actual age label only
Age range only
Both actual age label and age range
Age distribution posterior

multiple_choice_question.text: How is the proposed annotation (age distribution posterior) obtained?
choices: By directly asking annotators to estimate the age range
By averaging the predictions of several existing age estimation models
By comparing the query image with reference images of known ages
By analyzing the facial features that are highly correlated with age

multiple_choice_question.text: What key capability of the proposed network is illustrated in this figure?
choices: Estimating age solely based on facial wrinkles and skin sagging.
Jointly estimating both the ordinal classification and age posterior distribution.
Transforming age posterior distribution into a single, most probable age.
Achieving perfect accuracy in age estimation compared to baseline methods.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this plot reveal about human performance in Test I (guessing actual age)?
choices: Humans are highly accurate in estimating the actual age of individuals.
Humans tend to overestimate the age of younger individuals.
Humans struggle to accurately predict the actual age based on facial appearance.
Humans perform consistently well across different age groups.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key takeaway from the relationship depicted in this plot (Test II - Comparing Age)?
choices: Humans are completely incapable of comparing the ages of two individuals.
Human accuracy in age comparison significantly decreases as the age difference grows larger.
Human performance in comparing ages can be approximated by a linear function.
Humans excel at comparing ages, especially when the age difference is substantial.
The likelihood of a face belonging to a particular age group.
The probability of a face being older than a reference image.
The age posterior probability based on multiple age comparisons.
The difference between the predicted age and the ground-truth age.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of multiplying the prior P(a) with all likelihoods P(Ckm|a)?
choices: To obtain a uniform distribution of age probabilities.
To amplify the uncertainty in the age estimation.
To combine prior knowledge about age with evidence from age comparisons.
To emphasize the importance of the most recent age comparison.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the blue vertical lines in this figure represent?
choices: The ground-truth age ranges of the individuals shown.
The age posterior distributions predicted by the network.
Age comparisons between the query face and reference faces.
The confidence intervals of the age estimation model.
